title: Ticket #4137: Non-blocking authentication
description:
Authentication has always been a sore spot for blocking. We do the first few round-trips in a non-blocking manner - but as soon as we hand off to the ReliSock to do the "real work", everything blocks.

It's straightforward work to give the same treatment to the remaining condor_io layers involved in authentication.

Branch posted here:

https://github.com/bbockelm/htcondor/tree/non_blocking_auth

Includes a non-blocking version of FS and GSI auth.
remarks:
2013-Dec-29 08:39:02 by bbockelm:
After a few bugfixes, this branch passes NMI tests.

2014-Jan-02 10:56:12 by tannenba:
Here is the significant wisdom here (ideally to be part of the design doc):

Previously, HTCondor interfaced with GSI using using globus_gss_assist_init_sec_context() and globus_gss_assist_accept_sec_context(). This is problematic because these APIs block the caller while performing multiple synchronous network round-trips.

However, the GSS API does have have non-blocking native interface; the "assist" part of "globus_gss_assist_init_sec_context" is a wrapper library around the GSS API which provides a blocking API.

This work will change HTCondor to use the non-blocking interface, allowing a return to the main event loop handler between GSI network round trips.

Hooray!!!! :) :) :)

2014-Aug-07 16:20:33 by jfrey:
Code Review

  • In DaemonCommandProtocol, remove the call to CommandNumToTableIndex() in Authenticate(), PostAuthenticate() and ExecCommand(). m_cmd_index should already have the correct value, set in ReadCommand().

  • In DaemonCommandProtocol, does the CondorErr m_errstack need to persist between calls? Otherwise, why make it a class member?

  • In DaemonCommandProtocol::Authenticate(), you always call ReliSock::authenticate() in non-blocking mode. Shouldn't you consult m_nonblocking to decide if you want to be blocking or nonblocking?

  • In DaemonCommandProtocol::AuthenticateContinue(), you always call ReliSock::authenticate_continue() in blocking mode. Shouldn't you call it in non-blocking mode?

  • In SecManStartCommand::authenticate_inner(), ReliSock::authenticate() is always called in non-blocking mode. Should this be based on SecManStartCommand::m_nonblocking?

  • Should Authentication::authenticate_finish() be protected or private? No one outside of the class should be calling it, correct?

  • In Authentication, these new data members aren't initialized in the constructor: m_auth, m_continue_handshake, m_continue_auth. The destructor should delete m_auth, and m_auth should be set to NULL when the pointer is moved to authenticator_.

  • In Condor_Auth_FS, in the FS_REMOTE code, you dprintf() an empty m_new_dir instead of the template path.

  • In Condor_Auth_FS, for both the local and remote cases, the code around condor_mkstemp is overly convoluted. Why not leave new_dir as a char* that's strdup()'d and then free()'d after use? When condor_mkstemp() fails, it's clearer if you set m_new_dir to "".

  • In Condor_Auth_X509, authenticate_server_gss_complete() could be folded into authenticate_server_gss(). That may allow you to turn m_client_name into a local variable.

  • In Condor_Auth_X509, I don't see why m_input_token and m_input_token_desc need to be class members. They're only used in authenticate_server_gss() and they're always freed before the function returns. It appears that m_input_chan_bindings and m_mech_type are unnecessary as well. You could just use GSS_C_NO_CHANNEL_BINDINGS and GSS_C_NO_OID when calling gss_accept_sec_context().

2014-Aug-07 20:28:17 by bbockelm:
I believe I took care of everything except m_errstack; I'm not convinced that a badly written authentication object won't stash and use it between calls.

Ran the code through batlab and tests looked good.

Per our phone, merging this - any further fixes can go straight to master.

2014-Sep-10 13:43:31 by jfrey:
You didn't address the concern about SecManStartCommand::authenticate_inner() also calling ReliSock::authenticate() in non-blocking mode.
